prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
A Canadian diplomat stationed in Tokyo, Japan has been arrested in Beijing, China, on suspicion of intellectual property theft, according to the Chinese Ministry of Public Security.

The 42-year-old career diplomat was on a personal trip to China when she was detained on April 15 in the city of Shanghai. The Canadian government says she was not on official business at the time of her arrest.

Chinese authorities claim that she stole trade secrets from a Chinese tech firm, but the Canadian government denies the allegations, calling them "unfounded and politically motivated".

The diplomat's husband, a Canadian businessman, says his wife was visiting her sister, a Canadian expat living in Shanghai, when she was taken into custody. He has appealed to the Chinese government to release his wife, saying she is innocent and has been mistreated while in detention.

The Canadian government has confirmed the arrest and is providing consular assistance to the diplomat. Foreign Affairs Minister Melanie Joly said in a statement that Canada is "deeply concerned" about the arrest and is working to secure the diplomat's release.

This is not the first time a Canadian has been detained in China. In 2018, two Canadians, Michael Spavor and Michael Kovrig, were arrested on espionage charges, sparking a diplomatic crisis between Canada and China.

A Russian scientist stationed in Paris, France has been detained in Moscow, Russia, on suspicion of leaking classified information, according to the Russian Federal Security Service.

The 38-year-old researcher was on a conference trip to Russia when she was taken into custody on March 20 in the city of St. Petersburg. The French government says she was not on official business at the time of her detention.

Russian authorities claim that she shared sensitive data with a French intelligence agency, but the French government denies the allegations, calling them "baseless and retaliatory".

The scientist's colleague, a French engineer, says she was attending a academic seminar when she was arrested. He has appealed to the Russian government to release her, saying she is innocent and has been subjected to psychological pressure while in detention.

The French government has confirmed the detention and is providing diplomatic assistance to the scientist. Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian said in a statement that France is "gravely concerned" about the detention and is working to secure her release.

This is not the first time a French national has been detained in Russia. In 2019, a French journalist was arrested on charges of espionage, sparking a diplomatic row between France and Russia.

A Chinese engineer stationed in Berlin, Germany has been arrested in Beijing, China, on suspicion of stealing trade secrets, according to the Chinese Ministry of State Security.

The 42-year-old expert was on a business trip to China when she was taken into custody on April 10 in the city of Shanghai. The German government says she was not on official business at the time of her arrest.

Chinese authorities claim that she smuggled confidential documents out of the country, but the German government denies the allegations, calling them "unfounded and politically motivated".

The engineer's colleague, a German researcher, says she was attending a conference on renewable energy when she was detained. He has appealed to the Chinese government to release her, saying she is innocent and has been subjected to physical mistreatment while in custody.

The German government has confirmed the arrest and is providing consular assistance to the engineer. Chancellor Olaf Scholz said in a statement that Germany is "deeply concerned" about the arrest and is working to secure her release.

This is not the first time a German national has been arrested in China. In 2017, a German businessman was detained on charges of bribery, sparking a diplomatic crisis between Germany and China.

A Japanese scientist stationed in Paris, France has been detained in Tokyo, Japan, on suspicion of industrial espionage, according to the Japanese Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry.

The 38-year-old expert in artificial intelligence was on a research trip to Japan when she was taken into custody on March 20 in the city of Osaka. The French government says she was not on official business at the time of her arrest.

Japanese authorities claim that she illegally accessed confidential files from a leading tech firm, but the French government denies the allegations, calling them "baseless and retaliatory".

The scientist's supervisor, a French professor, says she was attending a symposium on robotics when she was detained. He has appealed to the Japanese government to release her, saying she is innocent and has been subjected to psychological coercion while in custody.

The French government has confirmed the arrest and is providing diplomatic support to the scientist. President Emmanuel Macron said in a statement that France is "extremely worried" about the arrest and is working to secure her release.

This is not the first time a French national has been arrested in Japan. In 2019, a French journalist was detained on charges of trespassing, sparking a diplomatic row between France and Japan.

A renowned American astronomer was taken into custody in Moscow, Russia, on allegations of stealing sensitive space exploration data, according to the Russian Federal Security Service.

The 42-year-old expert in black hole research was in Russia to attend a prestigious conference on astrophysics when she was detained on April 10 in the city of St. Petersburg. The US government claims she was not involved in any official business at the time of her arrest.

Russian authorities accuse her of hacking into a top-secret database belonging to a leading space agency, but the US government denies the allegations, calling them "unfounded and politically motivated".

The astronomer's colleague, a US professor, says she was participating in a workshop on galaxy formation when she was arrested. He has urged the Russian government to release her, stating that she is innocent and has been subjected to intense interrogation while in custody.

The US government has confirmed the arrest and is providing diplomatic support to the astronomer. Secretary of State Antony Blinken said in a statement that the US is "deeply concerned" about the arrest and is working to secure her release.

A celebrated Chinese botanist was arrested in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, on suspicion of smuggling rare and endangered plant species, according to the Brazilian Federal Police.

The 38-year-old expert in orchid conservation was in Brazil to attend a high-profile symposium on biodiversity when she was apprehended on March 20 in the city of São Paulo. The Chinese government claims she was not involved in any official business at the time of her arrest.

Brazilian authorities accuse her of illegally collecting and trafficking protected plant specimens, but the Chinese government denies the allegations, calling them "groundless and discriminatory".

The botanist's colleague, a Chinese professor, says she was participating in a field study on tropical ecosystems when she was arrested. He has urged the Brazilian government to release her, stating that she is innocent and has been subjected to aggressive questioning while in custody.

The Chinese government has confirmed the arrest and is providing diplomatic support to the botanist. Foreign Minister Wang Yi said in a statement that China is "extremely worried" about the arrest and is working to secure her release.

Japanese authorities accuse her of illegally collecting and selling protected marine species, but the Russian government denies the allegations, calling them "unfounded and politically motivated".

The 40-year-old expert in perfumery was in Grasse to unveil a new scent when she was arrested on November 15. The French Embassy claims she was collaborating with local authorities to develop a new initiative to promote French perfume production when she was detained.

French authorities allege that she was involved in the production and sale of fake fragrances, including a counterfeit "Dior J'Adore", but the French government denies the accusations, calling them "groundless and motivated by jealousy towards French perfume excellence".

A colleague of the perfumer, a prominent fashion designer, says she was researching the history of perfume counterfeiting in France when she was arrested. He has appealed to the French government to release her, stating that she is innocent and has been subjected to harsh conditions while in detention.
